title: Easy Ways to Freeze Potatoes to Make Them Last for Months

steps.title: Clean the potatoes.
steps.content: Clean the potatoes. Give your potatoes a good rinse and peel off the skin (or keep the skins on, if you prefer). [1] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Optional: To keep your potatoes from getting discolored in the freezer, place them in a bowl filled with 1 US gal (3.8 L) of water mixed with 1 tsp (3,000 mg) of ascorbic acid . [2] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Boil small potatoes for 4 to 6 minutes and large ones for 8 to 10.
steps.content: Boil small potatoes for 4 to 6 minutes and large ones for 8 to 10. This short boiling process is known as blanching, and helps prep your spuds before they go in the freezer. [3] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source After boiling, soak the potatoes in an ice-water bath right away to keep them from cooking further. [4] X Research source A “small” potato qualifies as one that’s 1 1 ⁄ 2 in (3.8 cm) thick or smaller. [5] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source While you don’t have to boil your potatoes beforehand, the process helps prevent them from discoloring further down the line. [6] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Boiling the potatoes ahead of time also helps improve their texture and taste.

steps.title: Drain the potatoes and transfer them to freezer-safe storage bags.
steps.content: Drain the potatoes and transfer them to freezer-safe storage bags . Drain the potatoes from their ice-water bath and leave them whole or cut them into smaller chunks, if you so desire. Transfer the potatoes to freezer-safe bags (with 1 ⁄ 3 in (0.85 cm) headspace leftover) and pop them in the freezer. [7] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Pro tip: If you’re cutting the potatoes into smaller pieces, freeze the chunks on a baking sheet first. Then, transfer the frozen chunks to a storage bag so they don’t stick together while in the freezer.

steps.title: Form your leftover mashed potatoes into cakes.
steps.content: Form your leftover mashed potatoes into cakes. Shape your mashed potatoes so they resemble burger patties that are about a 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) thick. [8] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source For tastier mashed potatoes, choose a recipe with fatty ingredients like butter, sour cream, and the like.

steps.title: Freeze the mashed potato patties so they’re firm.
steps.content: Freeze the mashed potato patties so they’re firm. Transfer the patties to a baking sheet and stick them in the freezer until they’re solid. [9] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Transfer the frozen mashed potato cakes to a freezer-safe bag.
steps.content: Transfer the frozen mashed potato cakes to a freezer-safe bag. Now that the individual patties are frozen solid, place them all in the same bag and put the bag in the freezer. [10] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source To be safe, place sheets of freezer paper between the mashed potatoes as you store them.

steps.title: French fries
steps.content: French fries Slice and fry your french fries for 5 minutes, drain them of any leftover oil, and spread the fries out in a flat layer on a baking tray. Freeze the fries until they’re completely solid; then, transfer the frozen fries to a freezer-safe container or bag. [11] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source This works best for fries that are around 3 ⁄ 8 in (0.95 cm) thick.

steps.title: Hash browns
steps.content: Hash browns Make your hash browns using your preferred method, browning them a little bit but not completely. Cool your hash browns down, freeze them on a baking sheet, then transfer them to a freezer-safe bag and put them back in the freezer. [12] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Scalloped potatoes
steps.content: Scalloped potatoes Bake your scalloped potatoes until they're a light brown color but not completely cooked. Stick the potatoes in the fridge to cool them down quickly, and then wrap the top of the baking dish with parchment paper and a layer of foil. Transfer the covered baking dish to your freezer until you’re ready to eat the potatoes. [13] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Stuffed baked potatoes
steps.content: Stuffed baked potatoes Bake and prepare your potatoes as you normally would, and then immediately put the potatoes in your fridge. Once they're cool, wrap your baked potatoes tightly with parchment paper, transfer them to a freezer-proof bag, and stick them in the freezer. [14] X Trustworthy Source University of Missouri Extension University of Missouri program dedicated to research-based, practical public education Go to source

steps.title: Whole or cut potatoes
steps.content: Whole or cut potatoes Transfer the frozen potatoes to a pot of boiling water for around 15 minutes, or until they’re soft. [15] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Mashed potatoes
steps.content: Mashed potatoes Professional chef Ollie George Cigliano suggests “heating [the mashed potatoes] in the microwave at half-power for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, and adding additional time as needed. Once hot, stir in additional cream and butter, as desired." This process helps to both thaw the potatoes and prepare them for serving. Alternative: Place a light coating of melted fat (like butter) on top of each mashed potato patty. Then, broil them for a couple of minutes to thaw and cook the patties. [16] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: French fries
steps.content: French fries Set your oven to 475°F (246°C) and stick your french fries in for a few minutes until they’re completely browned. [17] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source This helps to thaw and cook your fries so they’re ready to be served. The exact time will depend on how crispy you like them, so check on your fries every couple of minutes to see how browned and cooked they are.

steps.title: Hash browns
steps.content: Hash browns Cook your frozen hash browns for a few minutes on the stove until they’re completely thawed out and browned. [18] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Scalloped potatoes
steps.content: Scalloped potatoes Stick the baking tray in the oven at 400 °F (204 °C) and cook them until the potatoes are thawed out, warm, and ready to eat. [19] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Baked stuffed potatoes
steps.content: Baked stuffed potatoes Set your oven to 350 °F (177 °C), unwrap the potatoes, and let them bake until they’re completely thawed out and reheated.
